item.title: Distributive Property of Modulus
item.description: Hey there. Since I don’t have much time today, I wanted to write an article on something small. Today, I proved the distributive property of the modulus ($\mod{}$): $$z(x \mod y) = (zx) \mod (zy)$$ Proving this is pretty simple: $$z(x \mod y) = z(x - y\lfloor\frac{x}{y}\rfloor)$$ $$= zx - zy\lfloor\frac{x}{y}\rfloor$$ $$= zx - zy\lfloor\frac{zx}{zy}\rfloor$$ $$= (zx) \mod (zy)$$ It’s a pretty nice property, and is especially useful for proving a very important property:

item.title: Socialfinder Part 1
item.description: I wanted to talk more about the project that I mentioned yesterday that I have dubbed “SocialFinder” (until I can find a better name for it). Description SocialFinder is a tool to help find people online. In particular, it’s a tool that tries to find documents, images, and other information about or relating to an individual online. In essence, a user would enter data about a particular person (such as a name, address, user account, etc) and the tool would try to find people that match that description by scouring the Web.

item.title: Privating Repos
item.description: Recently, I went ahead and private some of my repositories, including repositories of projects that I’m currently working on. I just wanted to quickly explain why I’m doing this. I’ve always wanted to hold myself accountable for the projects I do. Sometimes, when I do a project, I can become uninterested in what I’m doing or I’ll hold off on it due to other responsibilities. As a result, this leaves me with plenty of repositories, some of which are completed projects and others that are not.

item.title: An Interesting Fact About Logarithms
item.description: Today I learned something interesting about logarithms. Namely, that: $$\lg x \approx \ln x + \log x$$ with less than 1% error! The “proof” behind this is as follows: $$\frac{\ln x + \log x}{\lg x} = \frac{\frac{\lg x}{\lg e} + \frac{\lg x}{\lg 10}}{\lg x}$$ $$= \frac{(\lg e + \lg 10)(\lg x)}{\lg x \lg 10 \lg e}$$ $$= \frac{1}{\lg e} + \frac{1}{\lg 10}$$ $$ = \ln 2+ \log 2 $$ The above is approximately equivalent to $0.

item.title: Reddit Upvote Predictor Part 1
item.description: Hey there. I wanted to start working more with Tensorflow, so I decided to do a simple project where I try to predict the number of upvotes a given Reddit post will receive in a certain amount of time. This project is very suitable for machine learning, since the number of upvotes $y$ that a post gets can be predicted using a linear equation, of the form $\sum_{i=1}^n w_ix_i+b_i$ where $w_i$ and $b_i$ can be calculated through a method such as gradient descent and $x_i$ is the feature in particular.

item.title: Unfinished Projects
item.description: Hey there. I dropped writing for a little bit just to give myself a break and give myself some time to work on my project. Speaking of projects, this year I’ve been trying to cultivate more persistence. I feel like in the past I would start a project, go somewhat far with it, and then fail to follow through and provide something that worked the way I wanted. More critically, I didn’t feel satisfied.
